thread.title: Why the Facebook 'Dislike' Button Might Not Be a Thumbs Down
thread.title_full: Why the Facebook 'Dislike' Button Might Not Be a Thumbs Down

title: Why the Facebook 'Dislike' Button Might Not Be a Thumbs Down
text:
Facebook May Soon Feature a 'Dislike' Button 0 Shares Email Mark Zuckerberg has finally revealed that the oft-requested "dislike" button for Facebook is in the works -- but it's highly possible the feature won't take on the traditional "thumbs down" approach many people have expected. At a town hall on Tuesday, Zuckerberg said that the company hopes to launch the function soon but said he doesn't want the new tool to allow a down-voting and up-voting system, such as the one in place on Reddit. The news of the feature had many people excited on social media -- and included a few ideas of what the feature could ultimately look like when it goes public -- and how they could use it. 
Hate to break it to you Facebook but the entire internet is already a dislike button — josh groban (@joshgroban) September 16, 2015 
We don't need a dislike button, Zuckerberg. We need an "acknowledge" button. You could even get rid of the Like, "Acknowledge" is fine — Dana Schwartz (@DanaSchwartzzz) September 15, 2015 
Excited for the new dislike button on Facebook so I can dislike any baby pics, food pics or egotistical selfies that appear on my timeline. — Steven Turner (@StevenTurner_) September 16, 2015 Whatever form the button takes, Zuckerberg said it comes down to creating another way for people to lend their support when a "like" just doesn't feel right. "What they really want is the ability to express empathy," Zuckerberg said. "Not every moment is a good moment." 0 Shares
